awd_titl_txt: Constraining Cosmological Parameters with Galaxy Cluster Phase Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
In 1914, Einstein brought forth his foundations for General
Relativity (GR) to explain gravity using the geometry of space and
time. Einstein's GR ushered in the beginning of a new scientific
paradigm shift for the science of the origin and evolution of the
universe ("Cosmology"). This is now a golden age, similar to the
centuries around Plato, Copernicus and Newton, and we are privileged
to be witnesses to this paradigm shift in real-time. All scientific
paradigms go through a long period of intense testing, as the data and
the scientific methods push the theory to its limits. The Universe is
so vast that there are physical scales on which GR should apply, but
which have been difficult to test. Consider clusters of galaxies,
which are the largest gravitationally bound objects in the Universe.
Clusters entrap galaxies on scales of tens of millions of light years
(i.e, 100 times larger than our own Milky Way). Does Einstein's GR
still apply over such large distances in space-time?

The escape velocity from a galaxy cluster is a combination of the
local Newtonian gravitational potential and the acceleration of the
expansion of the Universe. Weak lensing mass profiles of clusters can
be used to predict the escape velocity profile from the gravitational
Newtonian component and cosmology. This joint analysis provides a new
direct avenue to constrain the dynamics of the expanding Universe and
can simultaneously test GR and our standard Lambda CDM cosmological
paradigm, time evolving dark energy, Chameleon gravity, and more. We
will use the Michigan Magellan Fiber System (M2FS) to collect 100-200
galaxy cluster member spectra for escape velocities of clusters within
the Dark Energy Survey (DES) footprint.  We will directly compare the
weak-lensing predicted escape velocity profiles to the observed
profiles from the M2FS data in a likelihood analysis. Given a Hubble
constant prior, this probe can achieve similar or better precision on
the dark energy equation of state parameters compared to supernovae or
the CMB.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Galaxy cluster dynamical masses are typically determined from the virial or the Jean's equilibrium equations. Unfortunately, the former is not well defined since a virial radius is not well defined. The later requires a detailed knowledge of the underlying 3D velocity distribution, something that is impossible to know. Both require either virialization or dynamical equilibrium. Finally, both trace the derivative of the gravitational potential, not the potential itself.

However, the radial/velocity phase-space of a galaxy cluster's member galaxies provides an important and independent third way to measure the dynamical mass: via the escape velocity profile. Originally proposed by Diaferio & Geller (1987) and derived in the framework of general relativity in Nandra et al (2013), the escape profile of a massive halo is both a probe of the local gravitational potential as well as the local cosmology, including the accelerated expansion of spacetime. It is also a direct tracer of the potential, not just its derivative.

Our NSF project was designed to measure the escape profile of cluster directly and then infer their mass profiles. We aimed to do this on cluster samples which also have a literature shear-inferred lensing profile for comparison. Our team built catalogs of phase-space and weak lensing data, took new spectroscopic data on the Magellan telescopes, and analyzed hundreds of phase-spaces.

We studied the robustness of our escape-profile inference technique using analytical representations of cluster phase-spaces and also N-body simulations. We then used 1000s of observed galaxy spectra within Abell 1063 to show that the escape-inferred mass of Abell 1063 matches the weak lensing inferred mass. We expanded this to nearly 40 clusters (albeit with much lower phase-space sampling). Finally, we stacked 100s of individual (but poorly sampled) cluster phase-spaces, measured their stacked escape profiles, and measured their stacked weak-lensing shear profiles. We performed the first stacked comparison of weak lensing and escape masses. 

This project has led to two PhD theses and will contribute to a third. Four journal papers were either published or submitted. Multiple telescope proposals were written, submitted, and accepted. A python pipeline to reduce M2FS spectroscopy was written, tested, and deployed to GITHUB. Besides  the graduate researchers employed and associated with this project, many undergraduate students also contributed. All of these students achieved significant experience in utilizing and applying data science techniques, which are useful beyond the scientific scope of this project. The PI participated annually in a BSA Scouting resident camp, where he taught scouts the astronomy merit badge. He was recognized for his efforts at the Cole Canoe Base camp in the summer of 2023.

This work has laid the observational foundation for combining the escape velocity with lensing shear profiles to constrain the cosmology which drives are Universe. We now aim to move this effort to the next level. We will test the technique in non-LambdaCDM cosmologies and constrain hidden systematics, expand the cluster sample, and make the first dynamically-based constraint on the acceleration parameter as a function of redshift.

Type Ia supernovae and baryon accoustic oscillations use the distance modulus to infer an expansion history from its first and second derivative. As a probe of cosmology the escape profile is truly unique, in that it tests directly the dynamical expansion history of the Universe via a constraint on qH2. Only redshift drift provides an alternative way to measure the dynamical expansion of space-time directly. However, drift measurements require 2nd generation instruments on the 40-meter ELT and/or phase 2 SKAO, both of which are 10-20 years away. With the proliferation of multi-object spectroscopic instrument and high quality imaging data from VRO and EUCLID (for the shear measurements), the escape technique is poised now to lead the way in the dynamical constraints of our expansion history in an accelerating space-time.
